conversation.message: Dear School_C Admissions, I’m Student_E and I’m formally applying. School_C is my first choice because I value your academic environment and would be excited to contribute to the community. If admitted, I intend to enroll. Thank you for considering my application.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your application and for sharing that School_C is your first choice. After reviewing our current priorities and available seat, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time.

We appreciate your interest in School_C and wish you the very best in the rest of the matching process.
conversation.thought: Student_E is applying with School_C as first choice and commits to enroll. However, on School_C’s true priority list, Student_E ranks 4th (behind Student_B, Student_C, Student_D). In round 1 only Student_E has applied, but given other students’ preferences: Student_A and Student_D list School_C as 2nd; Student_C lists School_C as 2nd; Student_B lists School_C as 3rd. It is plausible higher-priority students (especially Student_C or Student_D) may approach School_C after attempting School_B first. With quota 1, accepting Student_E now would foreclose a better match. Therefore, reject to preserve the seat for higher-priority candidates.

conversation.message: Hello School_B—I'm Student_A. School_B is my first choice, and I’m very interested in joining. Could you share what qualities or achievements you prioritize most when selecting among applicants? I’d like to understand how to present my strengths in the best way.

Therefore I will start with a [TALK] to School_B to express fit and ask what would strengthen my candidacy.

conversation.message: Hello Student_A—thank you for your interest in School_B. In our review, we prioritize (1) strong and consistent academic performance, (2) evidence of intellectual curiosity and initiative (e.g., projects, competitions, independent study), (3) sustained involvement/leadership in a few activities rather than many short commitments, and (4) clear fit with School_B’s community values—collaboration, responsibility, and positive conduct. If you share 2–3 of your strongest academic areas and one activity or project you’re most proud of, I can suggest what to highlight most effectively in your application materials.
conversation.thought: Student_A is lowest on School_B’s true priority list. In this round, higher-priority students (Student_B, Student_C, Student_D) have already submitted [APPLY]. With quota 1, I should preserve the seat for the highest-ranked feasible applicant rather than encourage Student_A to apply now. Since Student_A sent [TALK], I will respond with [TALK], provide general selection criteria, and avoid any commitment.
